properties.Name: PartyLocationGeographicCriteria

Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: LocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: GeographicCriteriaId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Geographic Criteria.

{"entityDirectives":{"baseEntityReference":{"name":"PartyLocationGeographicCriteria","path":"PartyLocationGeographicCriteria.cdm.json/PartyLocationGeographicCriteria"},"description":"The one or more geographic criteria that are assigned or linked to a Party Location and by which they are identified or qualified from a geographic perspective.

These criteria can change over a period of time and are represented with 'period start date/period end date' qualifications, which represented the best case for knowing this information.    If the data is only randomly sampled or recorded then you could use a single 'date' to identify its recording or effective as-of date.

Geographic market segmentation is a technique for segmenting a market based upon common geographic variables.    

Specific Geographic Criteria are then assigned to parties in order to identify common characteristics that can be used for planning and analysis of the market segment.

Examples of Geographic Criteria include urban, rural, Southwest and East Europe.

The business organization identifies a finite number of Geographic Criteria that are used to identify parties.   These criteria will be unique to each business organization and focus upon that organizations specific information requirements.

The Geographic Criteria Type is the larger classification to which the Geographic Criteria belongs.

Geographic Criteria Type is a means of classifying, grouping or categorizing specific Geographic Criteria at a higher level for analysis and presentation.

The following are examples:

Geographic Criteria Type: US Region
Geographic Criteria: Southwest

Geographic Criteria Type: ABCD County Type 
Geographic Criteria: ABCD County Type A 

Geographic Criteria Type: City Size
Geographic Criteria: 50,000-100,000

Geographic Criteria Type: Area Density 
Geographic Criteria: Urban

Geographic Criteria Type: Climate
Geographic Criteria: Tropical

Geographic Criteria Type: Topology

Properties.Description:
The one or more geographic criteria that are assigned or linked to a Party Location and by which they are identified or qualified from a geographic perspective.

These criteria can change over a period of time and are represented with 'period start date/period end date' qualifications, which represented the best case for knowing this information.    If the data is only randomly sampled or recorded then you could use a single 'date' to identify its recording or effective as-of date.

Geographic market segmentation is a technique for segmenting a market based upon common geographic variables.    

Specific Geographic Criteria are then assigned to parties in order to identify common characteristics that can be used for planning and analysis of the market segment.

Examples of Geographic Criteria include urban, rural, Southwest and East Europe.

The business organization identifies a finite number of Geographic Criteria that are used to identify parties.   These criteria will be unique to each business organization and focus upon that organizations specific information requirements.

The Geographic Criteria Type is the larger classification to which the Geographic Criteria belongs.

Geographic Criteria Type is a means of classifying, grouping or categorizing specific Geographic Criteria at a higher level for analysis and presentation.

The following are examples:

Geographic Criteria Type: US Region
Geographic Criteria: Southwest

Geographic Criteria Type: ABCD County Type 
Geographic Criteria: ABCD County Type A 

Geographic Criteria Type: City Size
Geographic Criteria: 50,000-100,000

Geographic Criteria Type: Area Density 
Geographic Criteria: Urban

Geographic Criteria Type: Climate
Geographic Criteria: Tropical

Geographic Criteria Type: Topology
Geographic Criteria: Desert
